META.project_subtitle: A Texas City explosion killed 15, injured 170 and rattled a community. Petroleum refiners promised change. 10 years later, workers are still dying.

OVERVIEW.headline: Texas City rocked by refinery explosion
OVERVIEW.shareline_1: This is a very interesting fact from the story
OVERVIEW.text:
This is the story itself.

It’s really interesting. You should read it and share it with all of your friends. If you don’t you’re a bad person.

Also, aren’t dinosaurs just the coolest? Seriously, who doesn’t love Jurassic Park and some incredibly smart velociraptors.
OVERVIEW.findings:
• This is our first finding. It is the most important. People will be impressed.
  • This is our second finding. It is still pretty important. We are pulling people in!
  • This is our last finding. Go out with style - it will be a big one!

DATA.headline: The Data
DATA.shareline_1: This is a very interesting fact from the story
DATA.text:
This is the story itself.

It’s really interesting. You should read it and share it with all of your friends. If you don’t you’re a bad person.

Also, aren’t dinosaurs just the coolest? Seriously, who doesn’t love Jurassic Park and some incredibly smart velociraptors.

SLIDESHOW.Caption: Firefighters pour water on the smoldering ISOM unit following the explosion that rocked the BP refinery Wednesday, March 23, 2005, in Texas City, Texas.
Damaged storage tanks and a destroyed trailer are seen by the blast site at the refinery plant in Texas City days after the explosion.

Juanita Ramos, widow of victim Art Ramos, embraces Margaret Jasso three days after the explosion. Art Ramos, 59, was a supervisor with Jacob Engineering (a subsidiary of J.E. Merit) working at the BP refinery.
David Leining, a BP employee, suffered two broken ankles from the explosion.
A refinery employee reacts after news of deaths at BP refinery in Texas City.
BP employees await further instructions from officials outside of the refinery in Texas City just after the explosion.
A week after the blast, BP's Director of Operations Don Parus tries to keep his composure as he talks to hundreds of BP workers as they pay their respects to those killed.
A devastated mobile unit at BP illustrates the risk associated with such structures.
SLIDESHOW.Credit: U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board

SLIDESHOW.Caption: Maria Dickinson, of Houston, places flowers at an unofficial memorial in front of the British Petroleum plant in Texas City after the explosion.
Josh Biscamp,16, and his sister Jessica look out of a shattered window at their home in Texas City after the blast.  Their home is across the from the refinery.
Flags fly at half staff outside the BP refinery in Texas City the day after the explosion.
A BP employee waits near a safety sign outside the Texas City plant.  A memorial service inside the plant began at 1:20 p.m. - the exact time of the blast one week before.
Aerial views of the ISOM unit of the BP plant in Texas City a week after the explosion.
A trailer located in the immediate explosion area near the blowdown stack is completely destroyed.
SLIDESHOW.Credit: U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board

DB.Summary: A worker has died from injuries sustained in a fall on Monday night at Citgo Petroleum Corp's [PDVSAC.UL] Corpus Christi, Texas, refinery, said sources familiar with the plant's operations.
An air compressor malfunction killed a contractor at the PBF Refinery in Greenwich Township, the Gloucester County Prosecutor's Office announced.
killed when a tank that was estimated to weigh 12,000 pounds fell on him in an industrial accident in north Wichita,
Chevron Corp. had a detonation and fire in a furnace in the cracking 2 area at its Pascagoula refinery in Mississippi that caused the death of one worker.
At least three employees were hospitalized for burns after flash fire occurred while they worked on a heat exchanger. (2 later died)
Worker died after being crushed by cylinders that rolled off fork-truck
Contractor died while working in a confined space at a crude oil refinery. Valero said it was not work-related.

An incident occurred when Employee #1, a maintenance employee, was sprayed in the face with a highly corrosive solution of Hydrofluoric Acid and Propane when the sight glass of a flow indicator ruptured releasing flying glass and the acute poisonous liquid gas mixture. Employee #1 was put under a safety shower and rinsing agents were applied to his face and neck areas to mitigate the chemical burns received from the exposure. Employee #1 was taken to a local area hospital, and later died from his injuries.

OSHA's Oklahoma City Area Office began its investigation Sept. 29, 2012, at the South Powell Street facility following the explosion of a boiler, which killed the employees. The inspection was expanded to include associated contractors and ongoing maintenance activities during a turnaround operation. OSHA investigators found violations of the process safety management standard, which requires specific management of hazards associated with processes using dangerous chemicals.
Worker laying pipe inside a trench was killed when another pipe fell on the worker. Contractor for Mason Construction.
Contractor for OneSource Industrial was struck and killed by a train while driving a vacuum truck across railroad tracks.

CSB: 1 worker was fatally injured and 2 other workers were burned at the Valero refinery in
Memphis, Tennessee on 6 March

At approximately 11:25 a.m. on September 13, 2011, Employee #1 was operating a riding mower. It was his second day on the job and his first day mowing grass. Employee #1 had assisted two other coworkers in changing a deflated front tire attached to the mowing deck. The two coworkers left to return tools and pick up their lunch. A third coworker, who was also mowing grass, saw Employee 1 driving the mower along the pipeline. The coworker turned the mower around to go in the opposite direction and when he turned back around again, he saw that Employee #1 had stopped and was facing the pipeline. As the coworker reached the section's cutting end, he noticed that Employee #1 was still in the same spot and drove over to see what was wrong. He found Employee #1 slumped over on his side and the coworker called the supervisor. Emergency medical personnel were summoned. The supervisor performed CPR until the EMS arrived, which was approximately 30 minutes. They were unable to revive him. Employee #1 died from blunt force trauma, which occurred when he struck a 30 in. pipe and was pinned between it and the mower.
Contractor for Matrix Service Industrial Contractors died after falling 40 feet from a tank scaffold.
Worker pinned between railcar and loading rack.
Worker performing maintenance on a tower died after becoming unconscious from hydrogen sulfide exposure and falling 100 feet. Contractor with Koch Specialty Plant Services.
The worker was working under supplied air with a helper inside a hydrogen sulfide unit. The worker was leaving the job, and slumped over for unknown reasons.

At approximately 12:15 am, on May 27, 2010, Employee #1 and Employee #2 had completed their rounds and returned to the Shell Oil's Lubrication Plant front entrance guard shack when Employee #1 dropped to the ground. Employee #2 rushed to his aid noticed that Employee #1 was having trouble breathing, and called 911. 911 dispatched Los Angeles Fire and paramedics to the Shell Oil Lubrication Plant. Upon arrival paramedics administered CPR and transferred Employee #1 to St. Mary's Hospital. At St.. Mary's doctors attempted to revive Employee #1 however he was pronounced dead as of the 27th of May 2010 at St. Mary's at approximately 1:30 am. The determined cause of death was arteriosclerotic cardiovascular disease

On April 19, 2010, at the Motiva site in Port Arthur, Texas a 90 ton Link-Belt extendable boom crane was being used as an assist crane to lift a 44,000 lbs counterweight tray to a DeMag 660 ton crane. An employee was trying to insert lug pins that connected the counterweight tray to the understructure of the DeMag. The preliminary findings reveal that one of the riggers was possibly on a ladder attempting to insert the first pin on the counterweight tray that was approximately 1 to 2 inches below the DeMag's structure when the assist crane's pinned section of the boom failed, dropping the 44,000 lb tray on the employee. The employee was killed.

DB.Names: Daniel J. Aldridge, 50 | Matthew C. Bowen, 31 | Darrin J. Hoines, 43 | Kathryn Powell, 28 | Donna Van Dreumel, 36 | Matt Gumbel, 34 | Lew Janz, 41
DB.Summary: At 12:30 a.m. on April 2nd, while the seven outside personnel were still performing A/B/C heat exchanger bank startup operations, the E heat exchanger on the adjacent, in-service bank catastrophically ruptured. The operator in the NHT control room told the CSB that he felt the impacts of the rupture at his desk 350 feet away. The CSB determined that at the time of the incident two of the outside operators were likely on the top level of the heat exchanger structure (Figure 10), and the remaining five operators were most likely at ground level. All seven outside operations personnel were badly burned, and within 22 days of the incident, all succumbed to their injuries.

DB.Names: Natividad Andajo | Victor Villa of Midland
DB.Summary:
2 killed, 2 injured The accident occurred when employees of Northwest Insulation of Texas were performing
welding operations on top of a storage tank at the refinery. The four victims, all Northwest
employees, had just finished lunch on March 2, 2010. When the crew resumed work after the
lunch break a welder ignited vapors from flammable liquids within the tank. The resulting
explosion ripped open the top of the tank and the ensuing fire burned for more than an hour
before being extinguished by the refinery’s fire brigade. As a result of the settlement, Navajo
Refining of Artesia does not admit fault, but does agree to settle to a $400,000 fine.

On January 22, 2010, Employee #1 was a safety and environmental specialist working at a refinery. He fell from a tower in the Black Lake Unit, which was a nonoperational unit at the refinery, and was killed.
Worker was lighting a pilot on a boiler in a stream unit when the boiler catastrophically failed.

At approximately 11:00 a.m. on November 5, 2009, Employee #1 was removing wall-mounted, triangular brackets and mounting clips from an interior wall. While repositioning the aerial lift, Employee #1 was facing the controls and his back was to the wall-mounted brackets. The basket of the aerial lift became caught on a bracket, and when the basket released from the bracket, the sudden upward movement ejected Employee #1 from the lift. Employee #1 fell to the ground and was killed. He was wearing a full body harness with lanyard but was not tied off to the aerial lift platform.

On October 15, 1999, a flash fire broke out at Conoco's Lake Charles refinery. Employee #1 sustained severe burns and was hospitalized at the Baton Rouge Medical Center burn unit. He died as a result of his injuries in November, 1999.

At approximately 4:50 a.m. on April 29, 2009, Employee #1 was occupying a platform near a tank, Number 496, which was a roofless water tank 23 ft in height and 96 ft in diameter. He fell into the water tank from the adjacent exterior platform and was unable to escape. The water line was 7 ft below the top of the water tank wall. The walls of the tank were 37 in. above the exterior platform, which is less than the minimum 42 inches required. He drowned inside the tank and was found at 9:00 p.m. on the same day.
Employee Is Killed In Fall Through Floor Opening

At approximately 11:00 a.m. on April 11, 2009, two coworkers were deheading Coke Drum Number 11 at an oil refinery delayed coker Unit. The coworkers, located on the mezzanine deck, were wearing heavy rubberized protective clothing, removed all 12 bolts from the 8-in. goose neck flange on the bottom outlet and then placed the Head Jack Carriage under the bottom head and unbolted all 52 bottom flange bolts. The coworkers remotely lowered the motorized Head Jack 1-in. to 3-in. below the bottom head in an attempt to drop the head onto the Jack. Employee # 1, at ground level, approximately 25 ft west of Drum 11, was struck with 212-degree Fahrenheit water, steam, and steam condensate from the unbolted flange on the front and back of body. Employee # 1 was provided first aid and subsequently transported to the hospital burn unit with second-degree and third- degree thermal burns to 85- percent of his body. At approximately 4.49 p.m. on April 29, 2009, Employee #1 died.
On March 7, 2009, Employee #1 was struck in the head and killed by the headache ball of a 50 ton crane. The wire rope failed when the crane's whip line was two blocked.
On November 20, 2008 Employees #1 and #2 were killed in an explosion and fire after a line ruptured at the Sat-Gas (saturated-gas) Unit in a refinery. Employees #3 through #5 were injured.

DB.Names: Marion "Scooter" Hubert Odom III, 41 | John D. Henry, 33 | Daniel "DJ" Lee Johnson, 30 | Rocky Dale Strength, 30
DB.Summary: One of the nation's largest mobile cranes collapsed at a Houston oil refinery Friday, killing four workers and injuring seven others
On January 14, 2007, Employee #1 was working near a pressurized water filter system. He was killed when a lid blew off the system and struck him.
Employee is killed when tank explodes
Gulf Services Contractor was operating vaccum truck when exposed to hazardous chemicals.

Primeau, 35, of Wallula, died Aug. 7 after being crushed by a piling weighing 11,000 to 18,000 pounds that came loose from a massive hammer. He was working to make sure that pilings were driven to the right depth for installation of a boom system. That system would contain any oil spills that might occur during oil transfers from ships.
Liening, a jounreyman employed by AMEX Electrical Services, was working on an idle residual hydrotreater unit, which was being reconditioned prior to restart.

At 6:30 p.m. on August 31, 2007, Employee #1, a refrigerated butane storage (RBS) operator, was instructed to close the block valves at night fall, following a hydrostatic test of Tank 300-1. Employee #1 closed the block valves as instructed. At approximately 8:45 p.m., Employee #1 was instructed by the supervisor to open the block valve drain on Tank 300-1 to stop the flow of water to the baffle pond due to high water. Another operator was instructed to close the valve on Tank 300-1 to stop the flow of water to the pond. Employee #1 traveled in a Ford F150 pickup truck to the pond, when he encountered high water, but he continued to drive the same route and drove into the pond. Employee #1 notified his supervisor by radio that he drove the vehicle into a "ditch", when actually Employee #1 was in the pond. He stated he was OK at approximately 10:30 p.m. Employee #1 called the supervisor again to inquire on how long it would be before someone would get to him. The supervisor stated an arrival time of a few minutes. Employee #1 replied again that he was OK. The approximate time was between 10:45 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. This was the last radio transmission between Employee #1 and other employees. Follow-up transmissions could not reach Employee #1. At approximately 11:00 p.m., attempts were made by employees who arrived on the scene to locate Employee #1. The water was high and there were no lights in the area except the headlights of the two vehicles searching for Employee #1. Employee #1 and the F150 he was driving were not visible. At approximately 11:05 p.m., a request for rescue personnel to respond to an incident at the north pond was made. Employee #1 was found at approximately 3:00 a.m. on September 1, 2007, drowned in the pond.
Hydrogen sulfide  exposure.
Contractor with J.V. Industrial Companies fell from ladder.

On July 21, 2006, Employee #1 was working for a company that produced chemicals. It was a subcontractor of BP Products. He was operating an aerial lift and was in the lift's basket installing an I-beam, when he was pinned and crushed against the basket. He sustained an unspecified fracture, and he was killed.

One man died and four injured when the roof of a storage tank collapsed. Inicdnet occurred in a tank normally used to store "mapitha?" at the refinery, 1660 W. anaheim St. Tank had been emptied for work. It had a "floating roof" designed to move up and down, but was held in place by 27 steel support legs; roof dropped when workers were cutting an inch from support legs to place new steel plates underneith.
Two contract employees were overcome and fatally injured by nitrogen as they performed maintenance work near a 24-inch opening on the top of a reactor. One of the workers died attempting rescue.

At approximately 8:47 p.m., on September 14, 2005, Employee #1 of an industrial cleaning company and often does contract work in refineries. In this particular contract, employer was given the task of cleaning waste tanks. Employees #1 through #3 were on the night shift on the night of the accident. After the tanks had been emptied of water, the employees descended into the tanks one by one to manually pick up solid debris. The actual worksite is an area which had several tanks or pits. The pits were of different configurations: there were rectangular, square as well as round pits, varying in depth from 15 to 30 ft. While the pits were separated by concrete walls, they were connected together at the bottom but were guarded by gates. After coming out of a 15 ft pit, Employee #1 was resting on the perimeter of the pits, preparing to enter into a 30 ft pit. He was wearing a body harness with a lanyard. Employee #1 was a six foot tripod, an emergency rescue equipment, leaning against a post. Upon seeing that his coworkers were having difficulty setting up a ladder for the next descend, Employee #1 walked across the top of the walls of the pits to help Employee #2 and Employee #3 out. As he walked across, employee #1, somehow pulled the tripod with him, the tripod fell and dropped into one of the pits, pulling him down with it. Before Employee #1 fell into the hole, his head hit the lip of the 29-in. wide pit, causing him to die of blunt head trauma. It is not clear whether his landyard got entangled with the tripod or that Employee #1 had hooked both his lanyard caribeeners into the tripod. According to refinery management, when the tripod was retrieved out of the pit, both caribeeners of the lanyard of Employee #1 were found hooked up to the tripod.
That death involved a contract worker hired to clean a vessel at the refinery, who lost contact with a safety monitor and was found unconscious in about 8 to 10 inches of water, BP said.

DB.Names:
Glenn Bolton
Lorena Cruz‐Alexander
Rafael "Ralph" Herrera, Jr.
Daniel J. Hogan, III
Jimmy Ray Hunnings
Morris "Monk" King
Larry Wayne Linsenbardt
Arthur Galvan Ramos
Ryan Rodriguez
James Warren Rowe
Linda Marie Hammer Rowe
Kimberly Smith
Susan Duhan Taylor
Larry Sheldon Thomas
Eugene White
DB.Summary: 2005 explosion and fire at a BP refinery in Texas City, Texas, killed 15 workers and injured 180 more
1 employee killed 2 injured in refinery explosion

On September 2, 2004, three employees were working on a boiler feed-water pump. A failure occurred and the employees were exposed to steam and hot water. Employees #1 and #3 died from serious burns and Employee #1 was hospitalized and treated for his injuries.
On June 2, 2004, Employee #1 died from a heart attack. Employee #1's death was determined to be from natural causes and not work related.

DB.Facility: TEXAS LP CORPUS CHRISTI WEST PLANT

DB.Summary: Fall from seperator cover
Hydrogen Sulfide exposure/massive heart attack

On August 26, 2003, Employee #1 was cleaning a temporary filter. For some reason, the filter exploded. A flash fire occurred and Employee #1 was engulfed and severely burned. Emergency services were contacted and Employee #1 was transported by helicopter to Herman Hospital, where he was hospitalized. He died 25 days later on September 20, 2003.
Employee dies 10 days after being burned in explosion and fire
Frank S. Richard died after falling about 25 feet from a steel structure inside the ChevronTexaco refinery in Pascagoula, Miss. Coded as "General contractors � Industrial Buildings and Warehouses."
electrocuted during AC installation outside of the refinery
Heart attack

On February 21, 2002, two employees were blocking the boiler feed water to the calcider. Two methods were available to accomplish this, using the double block valve or the root valves. The root valves, being the easiest valves to manipulate, were selected. Because of the location of these valves, the employees walked on the pipe rack. As his coworker began to access the pipe rack, Employee #1 slipped and fell 34 feet from the pipes. Employee #1 died at the scene.
3 employees injured, one killed in flammable vapor fire
Contractor dies, another injured in fire
Contractor, machinery maintainance man, dies from asphyxiation

He had been missing 24 hours before found hanging inside a tank, caught by his suspenders.He was working on a part of a gasoline-making unit
that had been shut down for maintenance for 30 days, according to the Times-Picayune
Maintenance worker was crushed by a temporary elevator at the Tesoro refinery in Anacortes, Wash

At approximately 10:30 p.m. on January 14, 2002, Employee #1 of Catalyst Process Specialists Inc., working at the Marathon-Ashland Refinery, was inside reactor vessel #2503 to knock down mounds of catalyst that had clumped together. As the employee began chipping away at the mound, the mound collapsed on the employee, engulfing him in the catalyst. Employee #1was engulfed by the catalyst. During his struggle to get free of the collapsing catalyst, more and more engulfed him, and eventually, the face seal of the helmet used by the employee broke allowing for the fresh air to be released into the catalyst and for catalyst to enter the mask. Supplied air was released from the helmet into the catalyst, causing it to ignite. Employee #1 was killed as a result of chemical burns.
Chad Grimes, 30, was killed and another man injured in a fire while working at the ChevronTexaco refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.,
RSI Inc contractor dies from asphyxiation in nitrogen purge
A worker died from burns when oil spilling from a ruptured overflow line at a reclamation plant ignited

CSB: On July 17, 2001, an explosion occurred at the Motiva Enterprises refinery in Delaware City, Delaware. A work crew had been repairing a catwalk above a sulfuric acid storage tank farm when a spark from their hot work ignited flammable vapors in one of the tanks. This tank had holes in its roof and shell due to corrosion. The tank collapsed, and one the contract workers was killed; eight others were injured. A significant volume of sulfuric acid was released to the environment. 1 killed, 8 injured.
Fall from ladder
Employee killed while in confined space–hydrocracker unit
Employee #1 was tungsten-inert-gas welding in a confined space at a refinery and suffered Argon asphyxiation. Employee #1 was killed.

DB.Facility: VALERO REFINING - TEXAS LP CORPUS CHRISTI WEST PLANT
DB.Summary: Employees #1 and #2 , who worked for a nested maintenance contractor, were finishing the turnaround of the sulfur recovery complex at a refinery. They were removing a 14 in. isolation blind from the overhead inlet of a horizontal receiver vessel. The vessel was part of an amine treating unit that had been emptied, steamed out, and drained a few days before. After several attempts, the overhead piping had been replaced and the blinds had been removed and reinstalled. Employees #1 and #2 were working from a scaffold when they were exposed to strong hydrogen sulfide emissions from the vessel. Employee #1 staggered away, but within minutes had lapsed into unconsciousness and died. Employee #2 managed to escape and reach grade level. He was hospitalized for observation and released with no lasting effects. The vessel had accumulated sour gas from a connected overhead gas line, tied into nearby sulfur trains that were operating at relatively low pressure. The source was a single leaking 12 in. gate valve that had been closed and locked out. Employees #1 and #2 were working without respiratory protection or gas detection equipment. The valve inspection program, lockout/tagout program, and respiratory protections were found lacking. At the time of the accident, the foreman was also overseeing other crews at the site.
Norwood was a 25-year plant employee who had three children and five grandchildren. Article says there was also a 1996 fatality at the plant.
Apparent heart attack while slumped in chair
Employee dies from exposure to hydrogen sulfide
One killed, one injured in refinery boiler explosion

DB.Names: Rollin Blue, Tom Rodacker, Ricardo Enriquez and Ernie Pofahl
DB.Summary: CSB: The 1999 incident occurred as workers attempted to remove and replace a leaky petroleum pipe which was attached to an operating oil distillation tower, known as a fractionator. Over a 13-day period prior to the accident, workers had repeatedly tried to isolate and drain the pipe, but leaking and corroded shut-off valves hampered their efforts. At the time of the incident, the pipe still contained a significant volume of pressurized naphtha, a highly flammable petroleum mixture similar to gasoline. While workers were in the process of replacing the pipe, the naphtha was released and burst into flame, killing the four workers. At the time of the fire, workers were positioned on scaffolding up to a hundred feet off the ground and had limited means of escape.

DB.Names: Dale Hamilton, 54 | Scott Shoffnor, 28 | Clay Yarbrough, 57
DB.Summary: "Three men working on a tank at an oil refinery were killed Wednesday in explosion that was heard for miles."

DB.Names: David Murdzia, 30 | Warren Fry, 50 | Theodore Cade, 23 | James Berlin, 38 | Ronald J. Granfors, 49 | Wayne E. Dowe, 44
DB.Summary: An explosion and fire erupts in the coking plant at the Equilon Puget Sound Refinery in Anacortes, killing six refinery workers who were attempting to restart the delayed coking unit following a power outage.
Employee Killed when run over locomotive train
Employee dies from overexposure to sulfuric acid
"One man was killed and another injured when a 40-foot tank exploded at Arco's Carson refinery Wednesday morning, company officials said."
Employee killed by acute exposure to hydrogen sulfide
Employee dies from exposure to hydrogen sulfide
Employee #1 was killed during an explosion and fire in a hydrocracking process unit.
Employee killed when reactor explodes

The fire was caused when the first stage compressor cylinder on the No. 2 RLE compressor pulled in liquid during the start-up procedure, which caused the cylinder internal bypass cover plate to crack. Hydrocarbon liquid and gas leaked from the cracked cover plate and was ignited from an unidentified source, which resulted in the fire and explosion. Three employees in the feed prep unit-Ellis Thornburg, Charles Hall, and Kevin Smith-were severely injured and sent to the Lubbock Burn Center. As a result of the explosion, Charles received third degree burns over fifty percent of his body, which caused his death eight days later on April 9, 1996.
Employee killed when struck by 700 lb shell cover

Employee #1, an operator in a fuel recycling process, was having problems with rocks blocking up lines and pumps in the equipment. Employees removed the 18 in. by 24 in. inspection cover from the top of an 8 ft diameter by 8 ft high tank and put a suction hose down into the bottom of the tank to suck the rocks out. Wearing an organic vapor chemical cartridge respirator, Employee #1 entered the tank, which had contained sludge and hydrocarbons, to take the larger rocks out by hand. He was overcome after approximately 10 minutes and died of asphyxia.

DB.Names: Ray Kelosky, Russell Beers, John Lee Pritchard, Clifford Walton
DB.Summary: 3 employees initially killed in explosion at refinery, 2 died later from injuries.
Workers were cleaning the 25-foot-high, 10-foot-diameter tank when sulfur dioxide and hydrogen sulfide gases inside apparently exploded.
a mixture of naphtha and crude oil in a tank without vents caused the explosion on March 20, 1995. A toxic cloud blew across a road and was ignited by at least one car, killing Tracy Kildebeck, 22.
